content: The Act may be cited as the "Lead Hazard Title X Amendments Act". Congress acknowledges that poor housing conditions contribute to various health issues, disproportionately affecting vulnerable populations such as children, minorities, and those with chronic medical conditions. For instance, in 2007, nearly 6,000,000 housing units in the US had significant physical infrastructure problems, and about 23,000,000 units built before 1960 have lead-based paint hazards, particularly harmful to young children under age 6. In the United States, poor housing conditions contribute to health issues, especially affecting children, minorities, and those with chronic medical conditions. Lead paint hazards in homes pose a risk to young children, with low-income families disproportionately affected. Asthma costs due to dampness and mold were estimated at $3.5 billion in 2004. About 17 million homes have elevated levels of allergens. The Federal Government found that 17 million homes have elevated levels of allergens, over 6.8 million housing units have radon exposures above the EPA action level, and radon exposures result in 21,000 lung cancer deaths per year. The government must continue leading projects to assess and correct health hazards in homes for safe housing for all. The Federal Government aims to provide decent, safe, and sanitary housing to every family in the United States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. Section 1004 of the Residential Lead-Based Paint Hazard Reduction Act of 1992 is amended to include definitions for "eligible applicant" and "housing-related health hazard." The curr_chunk defines a housing-related health hazard as a property that poses a risk of biological, physical, radiological, or chemical exposure that can harm human health. The curr_chunk introduces a grant program related to housing. The Residential Lead-Based Paint Hazard Reduction Act of 1992 is amended to include grants for reduction of lead-based paint hazards and correction of other housing-related hazards. The Residential Lead-Based Paint Hazard Reduction Act of 1992 is amended to include grants for reduction of lead-based paint hazards and correction of other housing-related hazards. Grants may not be used to assist federally assisted, federally owned, or public housing. The Residential Lead-Based Paint Hazard Reduction Act of 1992 is amended to authorize grants for evaluating and reducing lead-based paint hazards and addressing other housing-related health hazards. Grants can only be used for housing that meets specific criteria, and income verification processes may be established for grantee eligibility. The curr_chunk discusses obtaining income and program participation information from entities administering various programs such as the HOME Investment Partnerships program, special supplemental nutrition program, reduced price or free lunches program, and weatherization assistance program for low-income individuals. The curr_chunk discusses eligibility criteria for lead-based paint hazard programs under the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act, including various programs such as temporary assistance for needy families, supplemental security income, and other programs determined by the Secretary to meet family income requirements. Eligibility criteria for lead-based paint hazard programs under the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act include grants for approved housing affordability strategies and partnerships with private nonprofit organizations. The Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act allows private nonprofit organizations to apply for grants to address housing-related health hazards, with eligibility criteria updated to include partnerships with eligible applicants. The Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act allows grants for addressing housing-related health hazards, including renovations and remodeling activities. The Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act allows grants for addressing housing-related health hazards, including renovations and remodeling activities. The Act also includes provisions for the assessment and correction of housing-related health hazards and the evaluation of their effectiveness. Grants for activities related to lead-based paint hazards are also covered in the Act. The Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act allows grants for addressing housing-related health hazards, including renovations and remodeling activities. Amendments include correcting housing-related health hazards and adding provisions for lead-based paint hazards. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 1011 of the Residential Lead-based Paint Hazard Reduction Act of 1992 is amended to allocate not more than 25% of funds for grants related to housing health hazards, with an exception of $30,000,000 if $120,000,000 is appropriated. $250,000,000 is authorized for carrying out this subtitle. $250,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2014-2018.
